NewsLines.HeadLine: Iran's Khatami to begin struggle for more powers

NewsLine.NewsLineText: IRAN-POLITICS:Iran's Khatami to begin struggle for more powers

body.p: By Parisa Hafezi

TEHRAN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Iran's moderate President Mohammad Khatami is to present a bill to parliament on Tuesday to clarify his constitutional powers in a move that could lead to confrontation with his conservative rivals.
Khatami said last month he was ready to use all means, even a referendum if necessary, to assert his authority over hardliners who have blocked and parried his stabs at reform.
"I am going to present a bill on Khatami's constitutional powers to parliament on Tuesday," Vice-President Mohammad Ali Abtahi told Reuters.
Another bill, altering the rules for vetting election candidates by the conservative-dominated Guardian Council, is also expected to be introduced to parliament in the next weeks.

Conservatives, who control many key levers of power in Iran and are answerable only to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, have hitherto hamstrung Khatami's efforts to bring more democracy to the Islamic Republic.
Analysts say if conservatives reject the bills and a referendum is also disallowed, the mild-mannered Khatami might carry out his threat to resign which could lead to political turmoil in Iran.
PATIENCE RUNNING THIN

Khatami's seeming inability to overcome conservative opposition despite two resounding election wins in 1997 and 2001 has meant many people, wanting change and facing dire economic problems, are growing impatient with him.

"Khatami himself acknowledged his waning support, so he decided to push forward," reformist parliamentarian Jamileh Kadivar told Reuters. "Khatami has decided to...show he is determined to fulfil his promises through legal channels."
While the two bills are expected to be easily passed by the large pro-reform majority in parliament, they must then be approved by the Guardian Council.
The 12-man council has used its power to veto legislation it judges incompatible with Islamic law and the constitution to block most of parliament's reform efforts.

Khatami's powerful conservative rivals believe the constitutional powers bill would give too much authority to the head of executive over the legislative and judicial powers, as well as interfering in the supreme leader's authority.
"I don't think these bills would be easily passed through the filter of the Guardian Council," Kadivar said.
Other reformists believe the council may approve the bill to strengthen the president's powers, but reject the measure to alter its power to vet election candidates.

"It seems the Guardian Council will be more flexible on the presidential powers bill because they can control him through other means," reformist deputy Ali Shakourirad told Reuters. "But we have three important elections coming up and they don't want to lose their powerful tool to vet candidates."
Parliamentary and city council elections are due next year and presidential elections in 2005.
The bills, if rejected by the Guardian Council twice, would be sent to the Expediency Council, an arbitration body whose members are appointed by Khamenei.
Influential former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani on Monday rejected speculation the Expediency Council he heads would not approve the bill on the president's powers.

"These predictions that the Expediency Council will reject the bill are based on guess work," the official IRNA news agency quoted him as saying. "I hope everyone will cooperate to prevent the creation of any problem."

The Islamic Republic also faces the prospect of conflict on its borders in Iraq if Baghdad is attacked by the United States. Both Iran and Iraq, along with North Korea, have been branded part of an "axis of evil" by U.S. President George W. Bush.
